I've read a review that said half of Moore's "facts" weren't and he was just making up things

Did anyone see this very interesting documentary?

 
 I saw it. It's been my favorite of Moore's work, I haven't liked his earlier pieces nearly as much.
 
 His arguments come off well, in particular his exposure of the true nature of the NRA. I also liked his "interview" of Bob Hope, especially since he kicked the bucket recently and people were making a huge deal about how "great" he was. Meanwhile the work-farers in his restaurant chain are working for squat.
 
 Equally powerful was his interview with Marilyn Manson (re: his being targeted following the Colombine shootings because the kids listened to his music). I'm not a fan, I always thought people made an absurdly big deal about him (fans or protesters). He comes off so much more intelligent than most of the other people interviewed, it almost made me want to buy an album. Er, almost...
 
 All in all I thought he made a good point, although I don't believe the Toronto stunt. Toronto is so huge, and he was in the outskirts of the suburbs, so of course he found lots of people with their doors open. Maybe that wouldn't be the case in a US suburb, but it wouldn't be the case in downtown Toronto either.
 
 The cartoon by the people who do South Park was also funny.
montalban

All in all I thought he made a good point, although I don't believe the Toronto stunt. Toronto is so huge, and he was in the outskirts of the suburbs, so of course he found lots of people with their doors open. Maybe that wouldn't be the case in a US suburb, but it wouldn't be the case in downtown Toronto either.
 
 The cartoon by the people who do South Park was also funny.

 
 That bit puzzled me too, because my suburb of Sydney, is Wentworthville. It is a western suburb, and by Sydney standards the further west you go, the poorer the suburb (hence other Sydneysiders call us 'Westies')
 
 No one that I know of leaves their door unlocked. But conversely, I know a lot of people who open their locked doors to talk to strangers....
 
 Some years ago I worked for my local council helping frail and aged people. We'd go and collect them on a bus and take them back to a community centre for activities. Even when I just started, I'd go up to someone's house, say I was from the council, and they'd open the door straight away. Although they'd be expecting someone, I'm quite a large and ugly bloke (many people think I look like a 'biker'), so opening the door to me makes no sense, if you don't know me. Maybe that's just old people are more trusting or come from an era where you'd take someone's word.
 
 But it was odd that in Toronto they'd have so many unlocked doors.

 I really like your view on this film Mont. I just saw it today for the first time, and as an American I found it very interesting. I also kinda saw the dog-eat-dog theme more than once in the film. I really liked Marylin Manson's interview. I never have listened to his music, nor do i really care to. I really did not even know what he looked like until I saw him, but from everything I have heard about him I expected some drugged out freak that could not put 3 words together to make a sentence. Boy was I wrong! The best point he made was his last, when Moore asked him what he would say to the 2 kids from Columbine if he could talk to them. He said "nothing, I would listen." I think this speaks to the heart of many school shootings...nobody is there to listen to these kids. 
 
 And someone said Bob Hope? I don't remember Bob Hope, I do remember Dick Clark, is that perhaps what you meant Mizmaxx?
 
 I thought he took a rather objective look at guns and gun violence. I could not believe how evasive C. Heston (the supreme god of the NRA) was when Moore asked him legitimate questions. I had in the near past thought of joining the NRA, but after seeing Heston at his best and learning of his 2 rallies shortly after Flint and Columbine ( i had not known this previously), I decided that I don't want my name associated with this extremist. I support the right of Americans to own and carry guns, with common sense controls. (according to the people over at the gun control post, this makes me a "gun hater") I like to consider myself more of a realist. I think Moore was suggesting that in order to find a solution to the gun problem, we must first define the gun problem. Extremist groups screaming the "no more guns" or "cold dead hands" mantra only want to blame each other, and offer their own skewed solutions to a percieved problem. Only once we truly understand the problem can we find an answer to it. But that was just my view. ;)

 I agree with you, and Mizmaxx
 
 In a sense this is what Michael Moore is saying. He doesn't believe guns kill people, people kill people with the ease of a multitude of guns available.
 
 What Mizmaxx is saying is also right. The US is inherently a violent society. It is a society of conflict, where the state does not help you a lot, so everyone's forced by circumstances to compete against each other. This builds a 'me' first attitude. So everyone's out to get everyone else.
 
 This is why Canada, which has lots of guns, has little gun violence.
 
 Canada was the best example Michael Moore could use to reflect on American values. It is right next door, has a similar 'frontier' ethos, has a large ethnic population, has poverty. However, it has a 'You're down now, so we the state will help you back onto your feet' ethos.
 
 The USA extends this ethos into world politics, where-by if you don't get your own way, you bomb the place. Frustrated as youth may be, they see the President as a role model, and he solves most his issues by violence, or the threat of violence, so
 
 when
 1) Hopelessness
 2) Broken families
 3) Lack of education and useful skills
 4) Moral decay
 5) Media violence and acceptance of violence
 6) Anything you can think of that is a social ill
 come into play, that youth will reach for his trusty huntin' gear.

 For crime statistics in this state:

 http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2003/10/03/national/main576422.shtml
 
 
 With the excpetion of white males for sucide, black males and females, white females; all thier deaths due to accidental, criminal, and sucide add up all together were 14564 in 2000. All deaths by white males due to sucide are 13214. Where did you get your "most" from?
montalban

You source? It is a compilation of data. It says nothing relating violent crime with lower gun owernship or gun control. It is just data.

 
 What a strange comment!
 
 So, you're saying you can't read data?
 
 Fair enough.
 
 You know that our gun laws have been tightened since 1996. Now you're playing dumb.
 
 Further, You said on another post that crime rates had increased because of our tighter gun controls.
 
 You know now that this is not the case as I presented this same web-site. VoiceofReason provided an Australian Commonwealth site that gave stats for the nation as a whole, and it showed the same trend.
 
 Now out of the blue you're pretending you've seen this argument now for the first time, and you can't interpret the data as presented. That's so strange. And highly dishonest.

 Again, the odd comments. You must be an expert in Australian Social History, History of WWII etc. because you've made extensive comments on another post re: how I should kiss American arse for saving me from 'eating rice and fish-headds'.
 
 Suddenly Kelvin, the goal posts of these debate have switched, yet again with you. You're the most peripatetic when it comes to rules.

 Australia increased tighter gun laws = Australia has had less gun related crimes. You can do maths. I didn't realise I was debating a vegetable. :xbanghead

[QUOTE=montalban]That bit puzzled me too, because my suburb of Sydney, is Wentworthville. It is a western suburb, and by Sydney standards the further west you go, the poorer the suburb (hence other Sydneysiders call us 'Westies')
 
 No one that I know of leaves their door unlocked. But conversely, I know a lot of people who open their locked doors to talk to strangers....
 
 QUOTE]
 
 My house has its doors unlocked. I don't live in a big town, but for some reason all of my neighbors lock thiers because they think everyone's out to get them. I think that's the point this documentary was trying to make. I think his main point was our fear of eachother.. Im sure other people in other countries are afraid of eachother, but have just accepted human nature. We take it too far I think. We blame it on every little thing. And then, Ironically we use 'human nature' to justify our actions...
 I have a post like this in the Government section (before I know about this one and the one under gun control, but It's just about THAT point.)
 
 As for one of Mizmaxx's post. About Manson. Yeah, my dad's in the same boat. He used to think he was a mindless freak, but now he actually respects him. My brother and sister listen to Manson all the time, and never once have I seen any action of them wanting to go out an shoot someone. Irrelevant.. but hey.
